metadata.description: A curated list of Points of Interest (POIs) for the unfold.quest project, extracted from a user-provided document.
metadata.source_document_title: Soviet-Era Public Art in Purvciems District, Riga: An Urban Explorer's Guide

pois.title: Purvciems Microdistrict
pois.description: A significant example of Soviet urban planning and modernist architecture in Riga, developed extensively from 1970-1985. Designed as a comprehensive microdistrict for 65,000 inhabitants, it features various architectural series and public spaces that would have incorporated monumental-decorative art, though many elements may have been removed post-independence.

narrative_hooks.history: Developed from 1970-1985 as a model Soviet microdistrict, initially planned by Gunārs Melbergs, Ruta Paikule, and Dagnija Sila.
narrative_hooks.fun_fact: The district was designed using a hexagonal planning module and intended for 65,000 inhabitants.
narrative_hooks.architectural_detail: Features 9-story '602 Series' panel buildings with white ceramic tile facades and innovative 'French Project' monolithic concrete towers (21- and 19-stories tall).

pois.title: Minska Shopping Center
pois.description: Opened in 1975, this modernist commercial complex in Purvciems originally featured circular decorative openings and expressive brutalist elements. Named after the Belarusian capital, it was a prime candidate for Soviet monumental-decorative art, reflecting the 'friendship of peoples' symbolism.

narrative_hooks.history: Opened in 1975, part of the Soviet 'friendship of peoples' symbolism, named after the Belarusian capital.
narrative_hooks.fun_fact: Original design featured expressive brutalist elements and circular decorative openings, characteristic of 1970s Soviet modernist architecture.
narrative_hooks.architectural_detail: Known for its modernist commercial complex design with distinctive circular decorative openings and brutalist architectural elements.

pois.title: Mēbeļu Nams (Furniture House)
pois.description: Once the largest furniture store in the Baltic States, Mēbeļu Nams was designed by Raimondas and Sergejs Lubovičs. This significant commercial building in Purvciems features distinctive architectural elements, including a prominent decorative pylon, indicative of late Soviet modernism and its blend with commercial functionality.

narrative_hooks.history: Designed by Raimondas and Sergejs Lubovičs, it was once the largest furniture store in the entire Baltic States during the Soviet era.
narrative_hooks.fun_fact: The building was designed to be a prominent commercial landmark within the Purvciems microdistrict.
narrative_hooks.architectural_detail: Features distinctive architectural elements, including a decorative pylon with corporate signage.
